story: Created with Sketch.‘Cheaper power has always been our number one priority’Click to followThe IndependentAustralia pulls out of climate change targets agreed at Paris conferenceEmbattled Australian prime minister Malcolm Turnbull has abandoned plans to set a new emissions reduction target, following a revolt by MPs in his own government amid a potential leadership challenge.Mr Turnbull’s signature energy policy – the National Energy Guarantee – contained a pledge to cut Australia’s emissions by 26 per cent, based on 2005 levels, by 2030. The laws&nbspwould have helped the country meet its obligations under the Paris climate agreement.But after rebel Liberal Party MPs led by former prime minister Tony Abbott threatened to vote against the legislation – which would have triggered a crisis of confidence in Mr Turnbull – the PM decided to back down.As Greece burns, the Tories are signing off a laughable fracking billGlobal temperatures to be ‘abnormally high’ for at least four years2018 will be fourth-hottest year on record, climate scientists predictDealing with climate change by geoengineering Earth ‘would not work’It was Mr Abbott himself who signed Australia up to the Paris climate agreement, and it was he who at the time announced the&nbspemissions reductions target of&nbsp26&nbspper cent from 2005 levels.In 2014 he even said Australia could reduce emissions by up to 28 per cent, saying:&nbsp“There’s a definite commitment to 26 per cent&nbspbut we believe under the policies that we’ve got, with the circumstances that we think will apply, that we can go up to 28 per cent.”Despite the boast, he was later reported to have told colleagues he was “misled” while in Paris, and recently argued that using energy policy as a means of reducing emissions is “madness”.&nbsp“In politics you have to focus on what you can deliver,” Mr Turnbull said on Monday, adding the legislation would not pass parliament if it contained an emissions target.“Cheaper power has always been our number one priority when it comes to energy policy,” he told reporters.Mr Abbott has reportedly thrown his support behind Peter&nbspDutton, Australia’s home affairs minister, for a possible leadership challenge, though Mr Turnbull said he had the support of his party colleagues including Mr Dutton.Efforts to introduce climate change combatting emissions targets have repeatedly frustrated Australian politicians.In 2007 Kevin Rudd famously declared climate change “the great moral issue of our generation”, but was unable to push through the changes he wanted while PM, eventually dropping them. His Labour party successor, Julia Gillard, faced an aggressive campaign led by Mr Abbott against her plans to reduce pollution, in which she was called a liar and was personally derided by conservative campaigners.MPs his government has dropped plans to put an emissions reduction target into legislation (EPA)The current debate over the impact of energy policy on climate change has seen even greater polarisation.Mr Turnbull’s failure to win support for the emissions target, comes despite a recent history of worsening wildfires and searing temperatures. The bushfire season has typically begun during the country’s summer months, but Australia’s increasingly hotter, drier weather has seen the season brought two months earlier – well into winter.Meanwhile, in January this year, Penrith, 30 miles west of Sydney, was the hottest place on earth, hitting 47.3C, while Sydney was 44C.10 photographs to show to anyone who doesn't believe in climate changeA group of emperor penguins face a crack in the sea ice, near McMurdo Station, AntarcticaAmid a flood in Islampur, Jamalpur, Bangladesh, a woman on a raft searches for somewhere dry to take shelter. title: Puppy kitten sales ban pets nature animals
story: Named after tragic Lucy, a King Charles Spaniel rescued from a cramped cage on a puppy farm where she was repeatedly bred, the proposed ban will mean puppies and kittens will only be available direct from a breeder or rescue shelter.Environment Secretary Michael Gove today paid tribute to campaigners who had pushed for Lucy&rsquos Law as he outlined details of a consultation on the outright ban.Mr Gove said: &ldquoA ban on third party sales will ensure the nation&rsquos much-loved pets get the right start in life.&ldquoI pay tribute to the Lucy&rsquos Law campaign, spearheaded by PupAid, Care And Respect Includes All Dogs (CARIAD), and Canine Action UK, who have fought tirelessly for this step.                Brown bears kill and EAT park ranger &ndash leaving only his bones                Big Cat News: Forget the E-Type and watch a real jaguar in top gear&ldquoPeople who have a complete disregard for pet welfare will no longer be able to profit from this miserable trade.Prime Minister Theresa May pledged her commitment to crack down on cruel puppy farms last year in order to end the grisly conditions suffered by animals and also save young animals from health and psychological problems.The proposed third party sales ban follows other reforms in the Government&rsquos drive to bolster animal welfare.New laws come into force later in the year that tighten the compulsory licensing of professional dog breeders and prevents the sale of puppies and kittens under the age of eight weeks.Environment Secretary Michael Gove (Image: )Welcoming the announcement, vet Marc Abraham, of PupAid, said: &ldquoI'm delighted with the news that Lucy's Law is finally going to happen.For years irresponsible breeders in the UK and abroad, for example puppy farmers, have always used third parties to keep themselves well-hidden from the buying public.&ldquoBy banning third party sellers, Lucy's Law will ensure all breeders are accountable, making it the first major step in tackling puppy farm cruelty.&ldquoLucy's Law is a tribute to Lucy and all the victims of the third party puppy trade, and I thank all my fellow campaigners, supporters, parliamentarians, celebrities and ethical animal welfare organisations for their help in protecting the future health and happiness of this country's dogs and cats.                Spider horror: Terrifying spider that can jump SIX FOOT arrives in UKLucy, a victim of the trade to mass produce puppies, suffered with a curved spine and epilepsy, but was eventually rescued by Lisa Garner from her cramped cage in 2013 to become a mascot for campaigners.She died three years later.The RSPCA says the new system will ensure better health and welfare for animals and will also prevent animal lovers from being duped.David Bowles, assistant director of public affairs at the charity, said: &ldquoThe RSPCA knows first-hand the misery the puppy trade causes to dogs and families.Lisa Garner's rescue dog was the face of the Lucy Law campaign (Image: TWITTER)The only people who profit from this unscrupulous trade are the sellers.&ldquoWe believe it&rsquos vital to crackdown on this underground trade to provide much-needed protection to dogs and people, and welcome an end to the third-party sales of puppies.Coupled with the new licensing regime and proper enforcement, we believe the new system will help ensure better health and welfare for dogs and will better protect people from being duped by unscrupulous sellers.

title: no deal Brexit Dominic Raab Michel Barnier Brussels
story: The Brexit Secretary insisted the Government was fully prepared for any outcome from proceedings after meeting the EU&rsquos chief negotiator Michel Barnier.Mr Raab said: &ldquoOn the subject of no deal, our actions speak louder than words.In a fresh sign of tensions between the pair, Mr Barnier complained of a &ldquoblame game already growing around the possibility of the talks collapsing. But both negotiators yesterday agreed to work &ldquocontinuously over the coming weeks in the search for an agreement.Mr Raab and Mr Barnier spent more than two hours in talks at the European Commission&rsquos headquarters in Brussels yesterday.Standing side by side at a news conference last night, Mr Raab poured scorn on recent claims about the consequences of a no-deal Brexit, including suggestions the NHS could face a medicine shortage if talks collapse.                Brexit news: October deadline DITCHED as UK and EU move to seal deal                The THREE issues the EU and Britain must resolve He said: &ldquoSome of these hair-raising scare stories are very far from the truth.Mr Raab said that he &ldquolooked forward to demonstrating the Government&rsquos readiness for a no-deal Brexit when the Government begins publishing a series of 84 technical documents on contingency preparations tomorrow.The Brexit Secretary added: &ldquoThere are still some significant issues to overcome &ndash yes on Northern Ireland, I think we both recognise that &ndash but also on the future relationship.&ldquoIt&rsquos important to view the whole deal as a package.&ldquoWe agreed that we need to step up the intensity of the negotiations as we come into the final phase and we have agreed to meet regularly and resolve at the political level those outstanding issues that remain under technical consideration. Mr Barnier responded by dismissing suggestions Brussels was to blame for fears the talks could collapse with no deal.&nbspHe insisted the bloc had simply been sticking to founding principles.The French-born EU diplomat said: &ldquoTo be very frank, I do see a blame game starting against the EU in the case of a no-deal. The EU will not be impressed by a blame game and everyone should understand that.Mr Barnier also appeared to cast doubt on hopes a deal could be agreed in time for an EU summit towards the end of October.He said the EU and UK teams will negotiate &ldquocontinuously as Brexit talks enter the final stage.

title: Brexit news BBC host Baroness Fairhead UK EU withdrawal exports UK economy latest
story: Baroness Fairhead delivered a brutal dig at BBC host Justin Webb after he questioned her claim Britain could improve its exporting capabilities in the aftermath of Brexit.The Trade Minister suggested the UK could use its withdrawal from the European Union to increase exports from 30 percent of GDP to reach the top of the pack of G7 countries.But when the Today programme host tried to challenge her claim, Baroness Fairhead said: I think Justin you keep wanting to have a renegotiation of the Brexit referendum.Our export performance is pretty impressive. We have grown 10 percent in the last year and we are now at 30 percent of GDP. That, however, puts us in the middle of the pack of the G7.                Brexiteer's BRILLIANT reason why UK should NOT have second vote                Brexiteer SHUTS DOWN Chuka Umunna in fiery Brexit debate Baroness Fairhead suggested the UK could use its decision to leave the EU to aim at expanding its exporting potential much like Germany had after 2000.She continued: We want to be towards the top of the pack. You single out Germany and you are completely right.Germany is at about 47 percent. But let's remember that only in 2000 Germany was at 30 percent.Mr Webb had previously questioned her claim of improved global trade opportunities, saying: Doesn&rsquot the German example just underline, for those who say we shouldn&rsquot be leaving the European Union, their case?Brexit news: Baroness Fairhead shut down Justin Webb after he challenged her  (Image: YOUTUBEThe Update&bullYOUTUBEAsia House)Which is you can have this great export performance and you can have it, indeed possibly you have it because you are inside the European Union?Mr Webb continued: It&rsquos on people&rsquos minds and as you know the Government is going to come out with its case for what happens in the case of no deal etc.These things are very much at the fore. And I&rsquom just wondering whether you are trying to look at the sunlit uplands of sometime in the future when in fact at the moment we face clear and present danger to exports?Baroness Fairhead, alongside Internationa Trade Secretary Liam Fox, is expected to outline the Government's long-term ambition to boost British business in the aftermath of Brexit.The Trade Department is seeking to expand exports to around 35 percent of British GDP from the record 30 percent of 2017.&nbsp

title: Brexit news UK EU financial services City of London no deal preparation latest
story: In a repeat warning, Downing Street maintains the EU&rsquos economy will suffer if the City of London is not offered a deal which goes beyond Brussels current standard for third countries.In a new document, the Government cited independent estimations showing Britain's financial industry trades as many euros in the UK than the whole of the eurozone combined.The document reads: &ldquoIf mutual market access is lost, independent analysis indicates economic benefits from UK FS activity relocating to the EU27 will be more than offset by negative fragmentation and lost efficiency impacts.The UK stresses the importance of the City of London as one of Europe's leading financial services hubs and how its business underpins the wider European economy.Brexit news: UK warns EU will suffer unless special City of London deal is agreed (Image: )UK-located banks underwrite around half of the debt and equity, manages &pound1.4 trillion of European assets, according to the Government presentation.It adds: TheCityUK estimates more than twice as many euros are traded in the UK than in all the euro-area countries combined.The Government have made it clear that the EU's normal financial services offer to third countries will not work.Once the UK leaves the EU, we will maintain strong and appropriate regulation of our sector, given the exposure of our economy to the fiscal risk it represents, the document states.                UK can become an 'exporting SUPERPOWER' after Brexit, vows Liam Fox                No deal Brexit will DESTROY EU warns Hunt - but UK will PROSPERThe UK hosts the world's most significant financial centre, with markets and products that are often very different from what is found elsewhere in the EU.These differences mean that rule taking &ndash in the sense of an open-ended commitment to adopt rules without having influenced their formation &ndash will simply not work.It is important to find a mutually acceptable solution that encourages us to work together constructively, protecting financial stability and respecting the principle of autonomous decision-making.Britain is keen to avoid signing up to the EU's standard regulatory equivalence arrangements for third countries because the European Commission has the power to withdraw equivalence rights at short notice with no consultation.The Government calls for both sides to agree sensible timetables for winding down activity and avoiding retaliation.Dominic Raab and Michel Barnier resume their Brexit negotiations in Brussels today (Image: )It outlines its wish for UK banks to have a similar relationship to the EU after Brexit as Japanese ones do.The document argues the EU's deal with Japan can be used as a precedent for a deal because it includes a commitment to take into account the impact of one another's decision-making.It was released ahead of Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab's visit to Brussels, where he will meet his EU counterpart Michel Barnier for a short negotiation round.Prior to their meeting, Mr Raab said: I am looking forward to meeting Michel Barnier today, to progress our negotiations on the outstanding withdrawal agreement, Northern Ireland and the future relationship.Confident we can strike a deal that's good for the UK and our EU partners.While hoping to strike a deal, Mr Raab will be able to take a no-deal Brexit to the negotiation table as Britain steps up its preparations for crashing out of the EU.On Thursday, over 80 preparation notices will be published by the Government to help businesses and citizens prepare for a no-deal scenario.

title: brexit news fishermen wales trade deal eu deal
story: The Welsh Fishermen's Association (WFA) warned people would start going out of business after just four weeks if Britain leaves without a deal, with new customs checks and restrictions causing severe border delays.Sion Williams, a lobster and crab fisherman, who works near Nefyn, Gwynedd, in north Wales, said fishermen were increasingly concerned over the possibility of a no deal Brexit, which they claim would severely disrupt the transport of fish and other livestock.He insisted maintaining access to European markets was vital to UK's fishing sector, and expressed concerns over Britain leaving bloc without an agreement.He said: So much has been promised and people's hopes have been raised. I don't think anyone voted for things to get worse.                UK fishermen finally &lsquoBACK IN DRIVING SEAT&rsquo as Gove outlines Brexit                WE control our ports, not EU! MP lashes out at Brexit scaremongeringOf all the food producers exporting to Europe, the shellfish sector would be the most vulnerable if we have no deal.In Wales, 92 percent of registered vessels specialise in catching shellfish such as lobster, crab, whelks and mussels.In 2017, Welsh fishermen sold 90 percent of their shellfish to EU markets, contributing a total &pound38.8m to the fishing sector.Speaking to the BBC, Mr Williams added: Any delay in the transit of these commodities will cause a lot of problems as they are live shellfish and they need to be supplied as soon as possible.Fishermen say they would go out of business in just four weeks if Britain leaves the EU with no deal (Image: )If they're held up in ports, they can deteriorate, lose value and even die.It's been calculated that the industry would not be able to hold on more than four weeks of not being able to sell products into Europe.Because of the high cost of fishing enterprises, people expect to get a quick turnaround of money to support their businesses.He insisted the British and Welsh governments must provide financial assistance to UK's fishing industry if no Brexit agreement is made.                'SHARED challenge' May hits back after Italy demands UK take migran...                French fishermen shocked to find &lsquoDANGEROUS&rsquo WW2 bomb in their netMaintaining access to EU markets is vital to UK's fishing industry, Mr Williams warned (Image: )Mr Williams also said that tariffs of 6 percent for crabs and 8 percent for lobsters would be imposed if the UK does not arrange a substantial trade deal with the EU.A seafood restaurant chain in North Wales claimed the cost of shellfish would rise in the UK, declaring they were preparing for a Brexit backlash.But Gemma Webb, events manager at Dylan's, which has three sites in Criccieth, Menai Bridge and Llandudno, said local fishermen could see a good return from Brexit.She said: In some ways it could be good for the local fishing industry because surely if it is more difficult to get produce from abroad lots of restaurants here will be buying from local producers.British fishermen say shellfish produce would be most affected by a no deal Brexit (Image: )A Defra spokeswoman said leaving the EU would create a bright future for UK's fishing industry.She said: We are focused on getting the best possible deal when we leave the EU, which includes safeguarding the interests of our iconic fishing industry and maintaining consumer choice.A Welsh Government spokeswoman said: We are working hard with fishing communities to explore and, where possible, mitigate the impacts of a 'no deal' scenario but the threat is still very real.We have always been clear that full and unfettered access to the EU market must be maintained and are making the case for this with the UK government as the trade negotiations develop.

title: Brexit news Barry Gardiner second UK EU withdrawal referendum vote Labour latest
story: Hopes for a second Brexit referendum supported by the Labour Party dwindled on Tuesday after shadow Trade Secretary Barry Gardiner trashed calls for a new vote.Mr Gardiner, who backed Remain at the 2016 referendum, insisted the country had to respect the people's vote to leave the European Union to protect British democracy.Speaking to the Today programme, Mr Gardiner said: Those people who now want a second referendum are saying &lsquobecause you voted in the wrong way, we&rsquoll give you another chance to get it right,' that undermines the whole principle of democracy in this country.What I&rsquom saying in any situation if people feel the root to change is no longer a democratic route then you look to social disruption, perhaps civil disobedience, in a different way and this is playing with our democracy, it&rsquos playing with the foundations of the country in a way that is really damaging.                Even Remain voters TRASH call for new referendum as Farage comes back                'You want to RENEGOTIATE Brexit!' BBC host SHUT DOWN in heated rowThe Labour frontbencher continued: If people want to be able to achieve change through democratic means, if they feel that that is being denied to them, they then turn to other more socially disruptive ways of expressing their views, and that is the danger here.&ldquoWe have to respect people&rsquos vote in that referendum &ndash we told them we would, we must do it.Mr Gardiner also dismissed claims British voters were not aware of the consequences of their vote to leave the EU, insisting both the Leave and Remain campaign had made it clear their vote the future of the UK for the next 40 to 50 years.But the shadow Trade Minister's intervention was met with criticism from Labour MPs and Remain voters&nbspwho took to social media to vent their discontent with his statements.&nbspBrexit news: Barry Gardiner insisted a re-run of the vote would  (Image: )Exeter MP Ben Bradshaw, a supporter of the People's Vote campaign, said: I'm afraid Barry Gardiner in defending Brexit whatever the cost on @BBCr4today on democratic grounds completely ignores the democratic right of the people to change their minds.Colleague Chris Leslie said: When Barry Gardiner says giving the public a final say on Brexit would be undemocratic, perhaps he's missed the bit about #PeoplesVote being a democratic voice for the people.We don't stop having general elections if Tories win. We shouldn't deprive public their say on this.But a Deltapoll survey of 1,094 adults published on Sunday revealed that one in four Briton want the Government to deliver Brexit, with only 31 percent backing a new in-out referendum.The survey found that 40 percent would prefer to leave the EU with or without a deal, with 15 percent supporting calls for a vote on the final deal reached with Brussels.

title: Brexit news Jeremy Kyle Alastair Campbell UK EU withdrawal latest leave news
story: Jeremy Kyle could be seen hilariously reacting to claims by Alistair Campbell suggesting that British voters are now starting to fear the consequences of Brexit.As Mr Campbell said public opinion on leaving the European Union is starting to change because the real questions that are now starting to arise are really starting to scare people.Mr Kyle could be seen listening to Mr Campbell during his first talkRADIO show last week scrunching his face and shaking his head in an unconvinced manner.&nbspThe radio host also challenged the former Blair spin doctor on both Remain and Leave campaigns almost lying. What if you and your lot are right and we get a second referendum, and by a narrow majority we decide to reverse that and stay, what about the people that voted the first time?A referendum is surely about the people getting what they decide.Mr Campbell, who has been tirelessly campaigning for a people's vote on the final terms of the Brexit deal, defended his position insisting people are entitled to change their minds and should be given the chance to do so.He said: You have to accept that we lost the referendum, and I do accept that, but I think the reason why the Brextremists are so desperate just to get this over the line in March next year is because they do worry that the will of the people is changing. And the people are entitled to change their minds.&nbspBrexit news: Jeremy Kyle showcased an extensive range of emotions as he listened to Campbell (Image: TALKRADIO)I don&rsquot think the world is going to end but I do think some time in history countries chose their own decline, whether by accident or by design. I do think this is the case of a country chasing its own decline.Will it work practically? I think one of the reasons public opinion is changing is because the real questions that are now starting to arise are really starting to scare people.He added: Not many weeks ago we had all these talks about stockpiling food and medicines. Nobody mentioned that during the referendum, either on the Leave side or Remain side.Despite his support for a re-run of the referendum, a Deltapoll survey of 1,094 adults last week revealed that one in four Briton want the Government to deliver Brexit, with only 31 percent backing a new in-out referendum.The survey found that 40 percent would prefer to leave the EU with or without a deal, with 15 percent supporting calls for a vote on the final deal reached with Brussels.

title: Brexit news Liam Fox migration policy target UK Government plan latest EU withdrawal
story: Liam Fox suggested the Government could seek to review Britain's migration policy after Brexit to match British employment opportunities.Asked about whether he agreed with the UK's immigration target of 100,000, the International Trade Secretary told LBC: I think that one of the things that was clear from the referendum was that the public do not want unlimited movement into the United Kingdom.The public can differentiate between people who come here with a job and will be contributing to the economy and those who under free movement were able to come to the United Kingdom and use our public services without ever having contributed to them.Well that's the government target and we'll be reviewing what we do post-Brexit.                'PEOPLE'S Brexit or BUREAUCRAT'S Brexit? - Liam Fox SLAMS EU 'purists'                'Free movement will NEVER end! Farage RUBBISHES May's Brexit plans Dr Fox continued: I think we need to look in the future at how we match our employment opportunities with our migration policy.The big problem with free movement from Europe was that people were able to come to Great Britain without having a job and they were able to use our public services like schools and hospitals and housing without ever having contributed.I don't think the public think that is fair and neither do I.The intervention from the Tory frontbencher came hours after Theresa May announced she would take the moral high ground during talks with Brussels and offer the three million EU citizens the right to stay in Britain even after a no deal.&nbspBrexit news: Liam Fox suggested the Government could review the migration policy (Image: SKY NEWS&bull)The unilateral proposal from Mrs May would allow European citizens to continue accessing public services like the NHS and claim benefits.&nbspThe proposal will be nestled within the first release of more than 80 papers, which the Government will publish on Thursday, outlining contingency plans for a &lsquono-deal&rsquo Brexit across different sectors.The idea was welcomed by staunch Brexiteer Jacob-Rees Mogg, who told The Times: &ldquoI have always thought we should make a unilateral offer in this area.&ldquoEU migrants came here legally and the UK is not the sort of country that applies retrospective legislation.&ldquoThey should have broadly the same rights as British citizens &mdash no better or worse.

story: European Union politics expert Hans Vollaard suggested Brussels will see the earlier stages of its end as EU member states begin to slowly demand more control back to national governments.Prof Vollaard claimed that rather than collapsing immediately, the EU political system would first be crippled by a series of partial exits fuelled by the dissatisfaction with the European project.Speaking exclusively to Express, Prof Vollaard said: What I expect is that many other actors, whether it&rsquos parties, governments, member states, are rather willing to stay in the European Union but are nevertheless very much dissatisfied about the EU.Instead of leaving completely, and using the option of a full exit, they&rsquod rather withdraw from the EU political system partially.                Brexiteer economist warns Brussels THIS could end bloc                Juncker warned EU 'QUASI-RELIGION' spells trouble for future of blocThe Dutch academic argued member states could recover autonomy from Brussels in different ways, including putting an end to compliance to EU law or stop paying into the common budget.Prof Vollaard, however, added that EU countries will continue to believe that partially remaining is better than leaving completely.He continued: Even in the case of Greece, the majority of the voters, parties and the Government in the midst of the Euro debt crisis, they still wanted to remain in the EU.That&rsquos because they can see that remaining is better, or less worse, than leaving.EU news: Hans Vollaard warned dissatisfaction with the EU could kickstart its dissolution (Image: )Prof Vollard also insisted that the dissatisfaction plaguing the EU could not be addressed due to the erging demands of single states clashing with other members.&nbspHe added: There are limited possibilities to fix the EU to such an extent the dissatisfaction will become less.If the Southern Europeans get what they want, meaning effective measures to address the migration problems which are key issues in Slovenia, Italy and Greece, that will require much more solidarity from the north of Europe and the north of Europe is less willing to do so.Effective ways to address this dissatisfaction are not available for the most dissatisfied voices.Forecasts of the dire future of the EU bloc have exponentially increased since the Brexit vote, with Brexiteers predicting Eurocrats could see their project fail before 2070.EU news: Prof Vollaard argued there are limited possibilities to fix the EU (Image: YOUTUBESharing Perspectives Foundation)Asked about previous forecasts on the future of the bloc, economist Andrea Hoss&ograve said: I said in my answer when talking about the 50-year horizon, I&rsquom not sure that the EU will be around in 50 years.I didn&rsquot give a year but actually, I do stand by that.The economist suggested the leadership of the EU had failed to consider the consequences that Brexit and key elections over the past year could have on the support for the European project.French President Emmanuel Macron spearheaded plans for the further amalgamation of the bloc with the role of a new eurozone finance minister.Ms Hoss&ograve continued: The leadership of the EU and the leading nations of the EU, who actually decide what happens there &ndash Germany and France &ndash they haven&rsquot thought the consequences of all these things like Brexit and the Italian elections and the tension with Central Europe, the Visegrad countries.They haven&rsquot drawn the conclusion that this direction of forcing the United States of Europe onto the people of Europe is not working.

title: Brexit news UK EU Michel Barnier Dominic Raab no deal latest
story: Mr Barnier told reporters the Brexit withdrawal agreement &ndash which contains three outstanding issues &ndash may not be completed by the European Council summit in October as previously hoped.Having met with Mr Raab, the Frenchman explained they still need to work on the Irish backstop, outstanding withdrawal agreement issues and a political declaration on the future relationship.The two negotiators have committed to regular meetings, the first of which will be next week, in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit with time running out.Asked about the possibility of Westminster and Brussels agreeing on a deal for October, Mr Barnier said: When deciding what is realistic and not realistic, you have to take the date that Theresa May chose for the departure of the United Kingdom from the European Union &ndash March 30, I think it's actually enshrined in law in the UK now.If you count backwards from that date, March 30 2019, the day on which the UK will no longer be a member of the European Union &ndash while remaining for 21 months, if we reach an agreement, in the single market, customs union and European policies &nbsp&ndash the countdown backwards from there has to take account of the time which is necessary for ratification.&nbspThat is a given, it will take a certain amount of time to ratify the agreement &ndash on the UK side and the European side.&nbspThat takes us for a final agreement on the withdrawal agreement and political declaration well before the end of the year &ndash I'm not going to say October, a few days here, the begining of November, but not much later than that.&nbspBrexit news: Michel Barnier plays down October deadline for withdrawal agreement finish (Image: EbS)After last week's short round of talks, UK officials conceded not much progress has been made on the Irish border, an issue that has virtually kept negotations at a standstill.Both Mr Raab and Mr Barnier displayed their commitment to including an operational backstop in the withdrawal agreement, with the Brexit Secretary insisting it must respect Northern Ireland as much as the Republic.Mr Raab also dismissed the chance of a no-deal Brexit after a number of warnings on either side of the Channel. He said a number of hair-raising stories are far from the truth, adding: The overriding focus is trying our best to get a good deal for the UK and EU.He also confirmed the UK will be leaving on March 29, 2019 regardless of having a deal or not.&nbsp                Fox suggest 'tens of thousands' migration target could be SCRAPPED                EU warned: Expert lists steps that will lead to bloc DISINTEGRATIONMr Raab said: We will be leaving in March of next year and will be prepared for all eventualities for the negotations. But, again, I come here with renewed commitment, energy, vim and vigour to put into the negotations to get ourselves across the line.The Brexit Secretary will brief Westminster on Thursday on over 80 UK no-deal preparedness notices, which are designed to help assist businesses and citizens in case Britain crashes out of the EU without a deal.Mr Barnier lashed out at the no-deal debate currently being had in the UK, insisting he beleives the EU are becoming victim of a blame game which is starting to materialise.He said: &ldquoI hear the debate in the UK, of course, about no deal.&ldquoTo be very frank with you, I do see this blame game starting against the European Union in the case of a no-deal.&ldquoBut, the European Union is not going to be impressed by that kind of blame game.In a bid to reach a deal, the UK and EU will hold continuous talks going forward.&ldquoThe negotiations are now entering the final stage, said Mr Barnier.&ldquoWe have agreed that the EU and the UK will negotiate continuously from now on.&nbspDominic Raab and Michel Barnier share a joke despite the tough Brexit negotiations (Image: EbS)EU diplomats are also growing worried that October might to soon to conclude the withdrawal agreement.There is definitely going to be a real push for October and we&rsquoll probably not be able to quite get there, a senior diplomat told Reuters.So, while it has not formally been confirmed as yet, an extra summit in November looks most likely.Gabrielle Zimmer, a German MEP on the European Parliament's Brexit Steering Group, said: It will be very hard.&ldquoWe didn&rsquot see any concrete proposal that would work on the Irish border issue. November is the last moment. December is already too late for us.

Ryanair calls on airports to ban alcohol before 10am&ldquoI took time off work to drive to the bank but was told by the teller I couldn&rsquot use it.&ldquoI had to go back to the website to try and get them to respond and send a new cheque.&ldquoBut I still haven&rsquot had a reply.Karen Joyce told the BBC she had to wait for 11 months to receive compensation after the flight she had booked for her 25th wedding anniversary was cancelled.&ldquoI have not received anything from Ryanair (Image: )When she did finally receive a cheque the bank returned it unpaid with an added administration fee.She explained: &ldquoI was totally dumbstruck.&ldquoWe were loyal Ryanair customers and for them to bounce the cheque as well I just thought was disgusting.She phoned a Ryanair customer assistant, but noted &ldquohe just put the phone down.She added: &ldquoI have not received anything from Ryanair.Ryanair issued a statement admitting that a &ldquovery small number of cheques were sent out without a signature and said these had been reissued.They blamed this on an &ldquoadministration error and added: &ldquoWe apologise again for any inconvenience caused to customers.Ryanair is currently locked in an industrial dispute with pilots in five countries taking strike action.&ldquoWe apologise again for any inconvenience caused to customers (Image:  )A strike on Friday led to 26 flight cancellations between the UK and Ireland, whilst action on July 25 and 26 resulted in cancellations for 100,000 Ryanair passengers.The Civil Aviation Authority, which oversees civil air travel in the UK, has urged customers to apply for compensation under European air passengers&rsquo rights rules.They could be due &pound357 for cancelled long haul frights, or &pound223 for journeys of less than 1,500km.

story: While the effects of El Nino in Europe are under debate, experts warn it could trigger another cold British winter this year.The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) said there is a 70 per cent chance of an event becoming established over the next four months.It would be the sixth to strike in the past 15 years with previous events happening in 200203 200405, 200607, 200910 and 201415.El Nino - which is linked to extreme weather events across the globe - is triggered by a weakening of the easterly trade winds over the Pacific. When will Cimaron hit Japan?&ldquoThey are associated with widespread changes in the climate system that last several months, and can lead to significant human impacts affecting things such as infrastructure, agriculture, health and energy sectors.Climate scientists say it is too early to determine what effect if any another El Nino will have on global weather patterns.Mat Collins, professor of climate science at the University of Exeter, said: &ldquoThe issue will be the size of the El Nino event.&ldquoWeak events happen quite frequently , there has been a lot of variability between 1997 and 2016.&ldquoIt could turn out to be a strong event or it could be quite weak, it will be a case of keeping an eye on developments in the Pacific.&ldquoEl Nino can have greater impacts on places like Indonesia and India where it can affect the monsoon.&ldquoThis can affect crops and this has a knock-on effect in the UK when it comes to importing goods such as coffee.Katie Greening, a meteorologist with The Weather Company, said this El Nino is slightly different from other events with rising sea temperatures concentrates towards the middle of the Pacific.While there is much speculation over the relationship between El Nino and the British weather it could lead to lower than normal winter temperatures, she added.She said: &ldquoFor a classic El Nino pattern, unusually warm waters build over the eastern tropical Pacific, near the coast of South America.Wednesday weather map  (Image: WXCHARTS)&ldquoThe last two classic El Nino events have been associated with very story: The reclusive leader, who saw in February's Korean People&rsquos Army celebration day with a missile parade, appears to be planning the same this time around.The Day of the Foundation of the Republic on September 9 is marked annually in North Korea where it is one of the most important festivals in Kim Jong-un's calendar - as well as a regular opportunity for major tests.And this year's event marks the 70th anniversary of the state.North Korea is known for marking national events and important anniversaries with missile launches - Kim Jong-un&rsquos regime fired 23 missiles during 16 tests between February and December 2017. North Korea: Trump declares second meeting with Kim ‘MOST LIKELY'According to satellite images of the Mirim Parade Training Ground obtained on August 12, the facility is currently housing 500 military trucks as well as a peak in activity from troops.Pictures also note the erection of a tent to feed the troops located on a helipad nearby as well as groupings of military and the preparation and expansion of storage shelters.This time last year every North Korea celebration day coincided with a missile test launch.According to North Korea watchdog 38 North, parade preparations were first observed in July and appear to be following the pattern noted during recent parades.The Day of the Foundation of the Republic on September 9 is marked annually in North Korea (Image: )                180 families to reunite in North Korea as relations thaw                 Tears of joy as families torn apart by war are reunitedThough there is no significant activity from the adjacent Mirim Riding Academy, which last year provided a cavalry honour guard.The same can be said for the Mirim Flying Club&rsquos nearby airfield, which for past parades supplied lights for a flyover.Should a missile test launch be planned training would begin in the next two weeks for the parade set to take place on September 9.Analyst Joseph S. The source, based in the North Hamgyong province on the border of China, said: &ldquoInspection units are being dispatched to public areas.&ldquoThere have been crackdowns on non-socialist behaviours in the past, but since these hadn&rsquot seemed to help the situation, they are now strengthening the crackdown to put an end to them.&ldquoWith the approach of the 70th anniversary on September 9 of the founding of the North Korean regime, the Central Committee has given special instructions to root out non-socialist phenomena, such as fashion choices and hairstyles that do not fit the socialist lifestyle.

story: The talks are due to take place in the Russian capital starting on September 4 (Image: )The talks are due to take place in the Russian capital starting on September 4.A number of regional powers will attend, including China, Pakistan and Iran.However, neither the US nor the UK, who have been fighting the Taliban in Afghanistan since the US invasion of 2001, will have a presence at the talks.A senior Taliban member stated the group will attend &ldquofor the sake of finding peace in Afghanistan.                Soldier who lost legs in Taliban blast to marry nurse who saved him                ISIS terrorists surrender to Afghan troops after Taliban ATTACKRussia&rsquos presidential representative to Afghanistan, Zamir Kabulov, confirmed the Taliban had been invited to the talks.Commenting on the meeting, he said: &ldquoIt is in line with efforts to launch the process of national reconciliation in Afghanistan.It is expected the Taliban will be represented by Sher Mohammad Abbas, their top political envoy.Last month the group held peace talks with the US in Qatar.A senior Taliban member stated the group will attend &ldquofor the sake of finding peace in Afghanistan (Image: )A six-member Taliban delegation met Alice Wells, a senior State Department official.This represented a major concession from the US, who had previously insisted the Afghan government must also be represented at any talks.The negotiations come amid a backdrop of a surge in violence in Afghanistan.Earlier this month hundreds were killed when Taliban fighters attacked and briefly seized the city of Ghazni.In a separate incident, suicide bombers from the so-called Islamic State killed over 40 people in Kabul this month.There are reports the Taliban are stepping up attacks in a bid to put themselves in a stronger position prior to the upcoming peace talks.Last month the Taliban held peace talks with the US in Qatar (Image: )British Prime Minister Theresa May has also announced that an additional 440 British troops will join NATO forces in Afghanistan.A total of 456 British soldiers and airmen died in Afghanistan between 2001 and 2015, with most conflict occurring in the southern Helmand Province.

title: Facebook Twitter Mark Zuckerberg social media accounts Iran Russia Cambridge Analytica
story: Facebook news: Facebook Inc and Twitter Inc said on Tuesday they both removed about 300 accounts (Image: )Facebook Inc and Twitter Inc said on Tuesday they both removed about 300 accounts, mostly originating in Iran.The social media companies responded to a tip-off from cybersecurity firm FireEye Inc, which claimed on Tuesday the accounts were promoting Iranian propaganda, including discussion of &ldquoanti-Saudi, anti-Israeli and pro-Palestinian themes.Mark Zuckerberg&rsquos Facebook, which is seeking to clean up its image following the Cambridge Analytica scandal, said in a blog post it had removed a total of 652 pages, groups and accounts, which targeted people in the Middle East, Latin America, the UK and the US.Nathaniel Gleicher, head of cybersecurity policy at Facebook, said in a blog post: &ldquoWe've removed 652 Pages, groups and accounts for coordinated inauthentic behaviour that originated in Iran and targeted people across multiple internet services in the Middle East, Latin America, UK and US.                Boris Johnson’s Facebook page SWAMPED with RACIST messages                 How sending one text or message from your phone could cost you your...&ldquoThese were distinct campaigns and we have not identified any link or coordination between them.&ldquoHowever, they used similar tactics by creating networks of accounts to mislead others about who they were and what they were doing.Facebook revealed in July it received the tip-off from FireEye about a network of pages called &ldquoLiberty Front Press and instigated an investigation shortly after.The investigation highlighted additional related pages with ties to Iranian state media.Facebook news: Mr Zuckerberg was asked to testify in Congress following the data harvesting scandal (Image: )The social media company said: &ldquoSome of them attempted to conceal their location, and they primarily posted political content focused on the Middle East, as well as the UK, US, and Latin America.&ldquoBeginning in 2017, they increased their focus on the UK and US.&ldquoAccounts and pages linked to 'Liberty Front Press' typically posed as news and civil society organisations sharing information in multiple countries without revealing their true identity.Twitter labelled the effort &ldquocoordinated manipulation.The influence effort, as FireEye described it, began last year and continued through this month, the company stated.                Facebook: Silicon Valley tycoon faces WORST day ever as shares tumble                Facebook crisis: Shareholders want to REPLACE Mark ZuckerbergFireEye said: &ldquoHowever, it is important to note that the activity does not appear to have been specifically designed to influence the 2018 US midterm elections, as it extends well beyond US audiences and US politics.Facebook&rsquos latest attempt to clean up its platform comes weeks after the organisation deactivated accounts originating in Russia for engaging in deceitful behaviour.The company said on Tuesday it found additional &ldquoinauthentic behaviour linked to Russia, but that the activity did not appear to be linked to the campaign tied to Iran.Speaking to reporters on Tuesday, Mr Zuckerberg stated it was crucial for Facebook to foster relationships with law enforcement, governments and other countries to share information.Facebook news: Chris Wylie, the whistleblower who lifted the lid on the Cambridge Analytica scandal (Image: )He said: &ldquoWe think that there's a lot of good work happening on both of those fronts.&ldquoThis is a top priority for our company.Mr Zuckerberg&rsquos remarks come after he testified in front of Congress after the lid was lifted on a scandal that embroiled Facebook in connection with data analysis firm Cambridge Analytica.The company harvested the data of 50million Facebook profiles to influence the outcome of the 2016 US presidential election, according to whistleblower Chris Wylie.In response to the revelations, Mr Zuckerberg was asked to testify in front of Congress and later to the European Parliament.Following the probe, Facebook has conducted an overhaul of its advertising platform, ramped up content moderation and hired additional third-party reviewers.

title: US customs enforce law Canada legalises recreational marijuana
story: Recreational use of cannabis legalised in Canada  (Image: )Customs and Border Protection officials said: &ldquoAlthough medical and recreational marijuana may be legal in some US States and Canada, the sale, possession, production and distribution of marijuana all remain illegal under US federal law.They also noted that anyone who attempts to enter the US in possession of cannabis may have their drugs confiscated.There is also the possibility that iniduals will face fines.Drew Dilkens, the mayor of Windsor, a town close to the Canadian border, reminded people to be aware of the difference between what is legal and illegal in the two countries.He said: &ldquoWe want to make sure that people who come here don&rsquot have a bad experience and that they&rsquore fully informed when they cross the border that the laws are different here.Residents in Michigan will soon vote in a ballot to legalise marijuana in October, shortly after Canada does so officially.It is expected marijuana will be legalised in the US state, meaning the drug will be legal both sides of the US-Canada border.Washington, Vermont and Maine have already legalised the use of the drug.Marijuana will still not be allowed across USCanada border  (Image: )However, the legalisation of marijuana will have no impact on the ability for the drug to be taken across the border, as it is controlled by federal officials.Mayor Dickens said: &ldquoThis bright red line at the border is something we all need to consider, because federal law will apply at the border, notwithstanding what&rsquos legal or not in either province or state on the other side of that border.Immigration lawyer Len Saunders added: &ldquoIt&rsquos basically black and white if you admit to a US border official at the US port of entry that you&rsquove smoked marijuana in the past, you will be barred entry for life to the United States.His advice to Canadians would be to remain silent and not answer any questions of this sort.Nine US states currently permit the recreational use of marijuana, with pressure growing for more states to follow suit.A further 31 states allow the medicinal use of cannabis.Marijuana legalisation is gradually gaining bipartisan support, with 62 percent of Republicans under the age of 40 supporting the removal of prohibitions on marijuana consumption.69 percent of Democrats also support the measure.

title: Taiwan El Salvador Taiwan China embassy
story: The US is &ldquodeeply disappointed by El Salvador&rsquos decision to sever diplomatic relations with Taiwan (Image: Getty)El Salvador is the third Latin American nation that has decided to break ties with Taiwan in just over a year.China claims Taiwan as its own territory and is ramping up a campaign to diplomatically isolate the self-governing island rival.Even though the US formally recognises only China, it maintains a de facto embassy known as the American Institute in Taiwan.Taipei has a similar quasi-diplomatic outpost in Washington.                World War 3: China training for AIRSTRIKES against US targets                El Salvador BREAKS OFF diplomatic ties with Taiwan in favour of ChinaThe spokesman for the US State Department said: &ldquoAlthough we recognise the sovereign right of every country to determine its diplomatic relations, we are deeply disappointed by this decision.We are reviewing our relationship with El Salvador following this decision.Tensions between the US and El Salvador have been heating up since President Donald Trump threatened to cut aid from countries that do nothing to stop MS-13 gang members from entering the US illegally.Jean Manes, the US Ambassador in El Salvador, said on Tuesday that Salvadorans need to demand transparency about how their government decided to switch diplomatic partners.El Salvador is the third Latin American nation that has decided to break ties with Taiwan (Image: Getty)Ms Manes said: I think you should know, exactly, all the details of the negotiation.She also wrote on Twitter that the US was analysing El Salvador's worrisome decision.Florida Senator Marco Rubio also criticised the country's switch and threatened to block funding for El Salvador, accusing it of being &ldquoagainst the US on everything.Taiwan&rsquos Foreign Minister condemned what he called China&rsquos campaign of luring away Taiwan&rsquos allies (Image: Getty)He tweeted: &ldquoWhy should we keep sending them so much foreign aid?Today I will begin work to end that.Taiwan&rsquos Foreign Minister Joseph Wu condemned what he called China&rsquos campaign of luring away Taiwan&rsquos allies with promises of vast financial aid and investment.He said: &ldquoIt is irresponsible to engage in financial aid diplomacy or compete with China in cash, or even in providing illegal political money.&ldquoMy government is unwilling to and cannot do so.

title: heatwave uk return hot weather forecast latest
story: Heres the latest forecast.Back to back high-pressure systems - which bring settled weather - had been long lingering over our islands. Hot temperatures are not uncommon in Britain during summer, but usually, it is mixed in with cooler and wetter days as unsettled weather fronts move in from the Atlantic.This is because the jet stream - strong winds high in the sky from west to east - shift about. If it is north of the UK and Ireland then hot weather can result. If it moves down over the country, that means low-pressure systems (wet and mild) are sucked our way. But this summer the jet stream has been jammed to the north of the UK and Ireland.This creates the conditions for high pressure to develop - and that means hot and dry weather.As August began this year, a dangerously hot African plume began to make its way across Iberia.While many Brits get uncomfortable working in 30C heats and commuting on sweaty tubes - our summers are still relatively mild compared to others.In North Africa and the Middle East temperatures regularly exceed 50C in the summer. Sudan in East Africa is one of the hottest places on Earth, with temperatures of more than 55C and very little rain a feature of life in a country horribly blighted by war and poverty.  Previous reports suggested Britain could bask in a 30C heatwave until October but, for this bank holiday, it looks unlikely to be a scorcher.Forecasts for that day point to a typically British mix of sunshine and showers for many across Britain.A North/South split will roughly divide the country — with more rain and wind in the North and sunnier spells in the South.This will be the case throughout the long weekend as parts of the North West especially face heavy showers at times.Even torrents of hail will thrash northern areas including Scotland, the North of England, Northern Wales and Northern Ireland during unsettled weekend conditions.High temperatures will struggle to get above the mid-teens Celsius.Further South will see more settled weather with lighter winds and longer stretches of sunshine.But it will still be cooler, with temperatures hovering around 19C to 20C from Saturday to Monday in the South East.The UK has been experiencing hot weather since April. But the last summer heatwave began on June 23 and lasted all July. A few days of rain in August didnt do much to restore green to grass in the south of England, with lawns and parks still looking rather brown and frazzled. The UK could be about to record its hottest summer ever, eclipsing the legendary heatwave of 1976.The Met Office have just released interim figures which suggest the summer of 2018 - the months of June, July and August - will enter the record books for one reason or another.Twelve years ago, Britain recorded its warmest summer since records began in 1910, if you use the calculation of the ‘mean’ temperature, a combination of the day-time and night-time highs.In 2006, the mean temperature at this stage in the summer was 16.1C (61F), exactly the same as it is now.The final figure for 2006 was 15.8C (60F), which means if we continue at the same rate until the end of this month, a new record will have been established.

title: young women getting 99 botox
story: After all, in the era of Love Island and social media, we’re all potential celebrities now. Even those of us who will never hit the big time have an Instagram audience waiting to “like” our every selfie.So this is just the logical next step towards making cosmetic surgery available to the masses, rather than the few.Some have argued that Superdrug Botox is actually a good thing, because it bridges the gap between the elite Harley Street options — where you pay several hundred pounds for an appointment with an “aesthetic doctor” — and the more backstreet treatments carried out by hairdressers with just a few hours of training.I disagree. Being able to buy a syringe or two of Botox when you are out shopping for your hairspray legitimises — and normalises — the act of injecting poison in your skin in the name of beauty.Being able to buy Botox over the counter, so to speak, makes it seem like no big deal — just another tick in the “maintenance” box, and as reasonable as tinting your lashes or getting your ears pierced.And that is the problem. All decisions we make about our appearance boil down to personal choice. And if it makes someone feel better to tinker cosmetically or surgically with their natural looks, that’s their choice. No one should judge them for it.But there is a wider problem.Increasingly, women think that whatever they look like naturally isn’t good enough. More and more, the “solution” is invasive cosmetic enhancement.A mainstream shop making Botox available for less than 100 quid is surely only going to add to the pressure some women feel to change their appearance using more than just make-up.Superdrug presents itself as responsible because it will refuse to treat under-25s, when other clinics will.That is shocking — not so much that some clinics WILL treat under-25s but that anyone so young could think they need Botox.You can’t blame Superdrug for this epidemic. It is simple supply and demand.The question is: Why the growing desire among women to look frozen?It’s not like you can get away with saying you’ve not had it when you have, because it’s so obvious.I’ve got a friend whose husband jokes that she needs to hold up little signs saying “happy” or “angry” when she feels an emotion, since her face is so paralysed by botulism.While I’m a big believer in your body, your choice, I’m also a believer in scratching the right itch.The truth is if you feel good about yourself, you look good. If you feel bad and lack confidence, nothing, no amount of Botox or fillers, will ever change that.Just look at Meg from Love Island, above, who, even after an estimated £40,000 worth of plastic surgery, is still massively insecure.Because it’s not what’s on the outside that counts, it’s what’s on the inside.The problem is our society tends to give far too much weight to the outside. That is especially the case for women, but increasingly for men, too.I realise all of this is easy to say, harder to act on. I’m as susceptible as the next person to comparing myself with ­others more beautiful — and possibly more airbrushed — and finding myself lacking.I’m just glad that, when that happens, I know the thing that will make me feel better is far more likely to be self-acceptance than Botox.After all, if you tighten a prune you don’t get a grape — you just get a tight prune!So the really big question is, how to achieve self-acceptance when we are surrounded by all these images of perfection?Well, we are all on our own journey with that one but I’ve got some suggestions which might help.The first is to focus on what you have, rather than what you don’t. And the second is to never, ever compare yourself to anyone else.Forget Botox, you can have that advice for free.You’re welcome.We all enjoyed cheering on the Three Lions players that would quickly become our heroes during the World Cup in Russia this summer.Sadly, those heady days are over and we were reminded of the seamier side of sport this week with the arrest of England rugby union ace Danny Cipriani.His embarrassing brawl outside a Jersey nightclub came hot on the heels of England cricket’s Ben Stokes’ trial over his clash with two men during a night out.Stokes was cleared, but what links these sorry sagas is our drinking culture, which dictates that consuming excessive amounts of alcohol is a normal way of letting off steam.Sportsmen are supposed to be role models, as they influence young people and need to keep themselves in good physical shape.But as long as we think it is OK to binge and push our bodies to the limits rather than sip a few drinks, then violence, injuries and stupid mistakes will continue to be a regular feature of our nights out.And if you are an England sports star, then public shame is just one of the tragic consequences – along with the end of your career – that you might have to face.Why should anyone be surprised at the news that sexual harassment in the police force is rife?Let’s face it, it happens everywhere. So why should the police be any exception?I thought they might hold themselves to higher standards. But no.A new survey reveals that dirty jokes, inappropriate touching, leering and being pressured to have sex are daily issues for many police staff.In a survey of almost 1,800 police staff in England, Wales and Scotland, half had heard sexualised jokes and one in five had received a sexually explicit email or text from a colleague.Shockingly, one in five had also been touched in a way that made them feel uncomfortable.Our head of police at West Ham is a woman.She is smart, tough, brave and would never put up with this type of behaviour.Part of the problem is that many women accept these actions as “normal” and don’t even know how to object. We must learn to stop putting up with it.But it is much more important that men learn what is OK and what is not.End of.Jacinda Ardern – the Prime Minister of New Zealand, who has continued to work since becoming a mother in June – was criticised this week for “using her baby as a prop” after she was seen breastfeeding her daughter at a public meeting.I guess whoever coined that phrase has never had the experience of looking after a baby who needs to be fed – right NOW.Nor will they have dealt with the very loud consequences of that failing to happen.Instead, what about congratulating Jacinda on doing such a great job of being a working mum?We said farewell to two legends last week, let’s remember them with this wonderful meme....So interesting that the day after A-level results arrived, more than 26,000 university places were still available.An Ipsos Mori poll found that while most students still think university is “important”, that is down from 86 per cent five years ago to 75 per cent now.Since a degree is expensive – and no guarantee of a job – you can see why people are questioning the validity of one.However, there is no viable alternative.There are just 10,000 degree-level apprenticeships available, compared with 300,000 university places, according to Sir Peter Lampl, of the Sutton Trust.We need to think how we prepare young people for work and we need more technical qualifications at degree level that offer the chance of a bright future.GOT a story? title: remoaners dream second referendum codswallop
story: Today, a Sun on Sunday poll shows that idea to be total codswallop.Voters simply want our politicians to get on with delivering Brexit.The majority of people have not changed their mind since the referendum. Our poll shows those that have are mostly Remainers who would now vote Leave. Project Fear has never worked, and it is not going to suddenly start working now. The public are wise to it.Our poll makes it clear that fudging Brexit would unleash serious anger among the electorate. The Government should take notice.Almost half of voters already reckon that the political classes in Britain are making heavy weather of Brexit, in the vain and misguided belief that they can get the public to change their mind.Meanwhile, the drop in support for Theresa May in the polls and Ukip’s rise is a further indication of what the public thought of her Chequers proposals.Millions more will abandon the Tories if Brexit ends up being fudged.Remoaners and Brussels have done their best since the Leave vote to make us think we made a terrible mistake and that the cards are stacked in the EU’s favour.Well, today’s poll is clear. We didn’t and they’re not.DEFENCE Secretary Gavin Williamson was right to stand up to France after they tried to bill us £2million for helping them stamp out a jihadi insurrection in Mali.Mr Williamson reportedly threatened to ground our choppers in retaliation. Good.The French also reneged on a deal to support a Nato mission in Estonia.As their closest military ally in Europe, we deserve better.Otherwise, next time, Mr Williamson will be entitled to say: “Zut alors! No more!”IT is scandalous that cops in the capital are reliant on weapon-detecting equipment donated by the public.Knife crime is the most deadly threat our youngsters face on the streets today.This week two men were killed and four teenagers stabbed in separate incidents.How can we expect cops to stamp out this deadly crimewave if they are reliant on public donations?The Government needs to properly start tackling this crisis. Lives depend on it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may tory leadership contest trevor kavanagh opinion
story: While Theresa May tours the capitals of Europe looking for peace on Brexit, war has broken out between diehard Remainers and fervent Brexiteers.Ex-Ukip leader Nigel Farage has stormed back into the fray with Vote Leave II, a remake of his 2016 referendum triumph.In the pro-Brussels corner, Superdry fashion tycoon Julian Dunkerton is forking out £1million for what must surely be a futile, last-ditch bid to keep Britain in the EU.And just to make things extra interesting for the party conference season, the stampede for Mrs May’s Tory crown is already unstoppable.Indeed, the question is no longer if, or even when, the contest takes place. It is whether the PM herself will seize the initiative and signal her own plan to jump before she is pushed.The undeclared contest has transformed Britain’s negotiating stance — from Theresa May’s meek, slow-motion surrender to a strident demand for a decent, honourable settlement. The good news is that while MPs have been away on holiday, Brussels has begun to blink.At long last it has dawned on our EU neighbours that they have more to lose from a messy Brexit than we do.Forfeiting the UK’s £40billion ransom payment — plus our annual £12billion contribution — would instantly cripple the EU expansionary budget plans and plunge poorer nations such as Greece into crisis.Car and pharmaceutical giants, not to mention French farmers, who export vast stocks to the UK, would be plunged into crisis. Cooperation on crime, security and defence would be at risk. Governments across Europe are now piling pressure on Brussels to see sense.Tory leadership wannabes have sniffed the way the wind is blowing.The Tories won’t pick another Remainer as party leader. Nor does this Government have a prayer at the next election unless it can see off Nigel Farage and his Ukip insurgents with a deal that satisfies the 52 per cent who voted Leave.This explains a sudden enthusiasm at the top for stating the blindingly obvious: Britain will survive a clean Brexit, while an obstructive Brussels will be diminished.After two years of being bossed around by EU bully Michel Barnier, senior Cabinet ministers are coming out as born-again Eurosceptics. Foreign Secretary and repentant Remainer Jeremy Hunt admits Britain will experience some turbulence, but says the EU will be damaged “for a generation”.His warning is echoed by Brexit supremo Dominic Raab, who has rubbished “Project Fear” stories about food and medicine shortages.While loyally insisting a deal is “still the most likely outcome”, Mr Raab insists Britain will cope with the alternative.Hunt and Raab are now openly jockeying for the top job — along with Home Secretary Sajid Javid, Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson, Treasury chief Liz Truss and a host of others.Significantly, Michael Gove seems out of the race after endorsing Mrs May’s Chequers sellout. So where does this leave Boris Johnson? If tens of thousands of grass- roots Tory supporters have anything to do with it, he would be way out in front. As things stand, they don’t.BoJo is out of office and fighting confected outrage over Muslim face masks. Enemies such as the priestly Dominic Grieve threaten to quit the party if he is elected.Under present rules, Boris needs enough support from fellow MPs to be one of the two candidates submitted to party members for a final verdict. His rivals will do anything to stop him — which is why party activists are demanding rule changes to allow any MP with 20 votes to enter the final ballot.Boris has gone quiet — but not for long. He is reportedly planning a nationwide tour — complete with bright-red battle bus — trashing Mrs May’s Chequers deal and calling for a clean Brexit.There will be plenty of opportunities for car-crash interviews and zipwire-style TV images. But the bookies aren’t the only ones making BoJo the clear favourite as Britain’s next Prime Minister.He names Somalis, Ethiopians, North and Central Africans and Afghans as being responsible for the knife-gang slaughter of young black and Asian men.“Race is part of the picture,” says the equality campaigner. “Failing to point this out impedes the fight against these crimes and imperils yet more children of colour.”He is right, isn’t he?But how long before this decent black man is himself accused of racism for daring to tell this unvarnished truth?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast temeratures plummet ahead of bank holiday weekend
story: The mercury is expected to reach a muggy 28C on Wednesday before more brisk autumn temperatures are brought in by the weekend.The blustery conditions come after a hot summer that brought in the driest June on record.Meteorologist Emma Smith said Tuesdays cloudy conditions were expected to continue into Wednesday.She said: It will be largely cloudy across the country, with outbreaks of patchy rain where the clouds are thickest.Wednesday will be the warmest day of the week with temperatures reaching 28 or 29C.But by Thursday, a cold front will push across Devon and Cornwall north - bringing with it blustery showers.Ms Smith said: Showers will become more widespread across Thursday, Friday and Saturday, with the main risk of hail and thunder in the north of the country.Its the first real autumnal change we have seen, its a real change in the type of weather.Overnight temperatures will cool down to 12C.The showers are expected to persist into Saturday and Sunday, with Ms Smith saying: On Sunday, there a chance we will see more persistent rain move into the west.By Bank Holiday Monday we will have unsettled conditions with showers and outbreaks of rain in the northwest.Forecasters have said the August 27 holiday will bring a typically British mix of sunshine and showers.A North/South split will roughly divide the country — with more rain and wind in the North and sunnier spells in the South.This will be the case throughout the long weekend as parts of the North West especially face heavy showers at times.In a forecast from 20 August, the Met Office warned: For Bank Holiday Monday, it is most likely to be unsettled in the northwest, with longer spells of rain and some strong winds.Drier and brighter conditions are generally likely in the South and East.This North West, South East split is then quite likely to continue.

title: jeremy corbyn aide oust pro israel mp guide
story: Nicolette Petersen, 61, has been at Mr Corbyn’s side since 1994 and wrote a how-to-guide to help voters rid Parliament of MPs who support Israel.Our revelation last night sparked fresh claims that the under-fire Labour boss is willing to tolerate anti-Jewish prejudice in his inner circle.In a pamphlet written before the 2010 Election, Mrs Petersen urged Labour supporters to support other parties if the Labour candidate was a “friend of Israel.”Her guide was published in the Spring 2010 edition of the Palestinian News magazine published by the Palestinian Solidarity Campaign - when her boss was a patron of the anti-Israel group.It says: “Read the Jewish Chronicle on line and look at websites that will show you who not to vote for.”Last night the Editor of the Jewish Chronicle blasted the guide saying: “This isn’t about helping Palestinians. It’s about attacking Jews.”Stephen Pollard told The Sun: “The recommendation that activists who want to rid Parliament of Zionists use the Jewish Chronicle for a hit-list of targets exposes the truth: that they use the word Zionist as a euphemism for Jew.A Labour Party spokesman said: “We don’t comment on staffing matters.”The latest anti-semitism howler came as Mr Corbyn claimed he “could not remember” if he had shared a takeaway with bloodthirsty boss of Hamas following The Sun’s revelations that he had bragged about it.Despite recounting the long dinner in a 2010 column for the communist Morning Star newspaper, yesterday Mr Corbyn told reporters A takeaway dinner? I dont remember any takeaway dinners.I have met many people from many aspects of the Palestinian cause as a way of bringing about dialogue, as a way of bringing about peace.During a visit to Scotland, the veteran lefty was also probed about comments made by former Labour MP Jim Sheridan who said he had lost “respect and empathy” for Jews because of the antisemitism crisis.Mr Corbyn said: Its completely wrong what he said. He did withdraw it later on, he has been suspended from membership, there will be an independent investigation - independent of me that is - so I cant comment any further. title: theresa mays electoral prospects depend on how she deals with mass uncontrolled immigration post brexit
story: As usual, she’ll be more focused on the advice of civil servants than her own colleagues or the guidance from her Chief Whip or the wider Cabinet.She would be unwise to ignore the evidence from polls and her own MPs, that the settled opinion of the country is simply “thus far and no further” and that instead the best way to get back onto the front foot is to work up more concessions to the EU and specifically, surrendering the last major red line: On mass uncontrolled immigration via free movement.We can see clues of further surrender in the fuzzy language from the Chequers agreement: The Government is commitment to “allowing citizens to travel freely without a visa, for tourism and temporary business activity…” But what will “temporary” really mean? Will our current free movement regime be rebadged as a “Labour Mobility Framework”?Such a move, speculated on in the media this week, would be politically toxic and very poorly timed. It would also betray her own instincts, which she rightly gave voice to when she became Prime Minister.Striking a chord with millions of people angry and alienated at their voices being ignored by the political elite on immigration and the downside of globalisation, delivered for her record poll ratings then and a real feeling of hope that at last people in power were listening.Yes, the main driver for the Leave vote was about democracy, independence and national sovereignty but it was also about the fundamental choice that a UK outside the EU would have: Who comes to our country and on what basis – decided by our own Parliament.Voters have noticed that the tightening of the labour market and record employment levels, as revealed by the Office for National Statistics last week, mean that at long last real wages – i.e. pay packets less inflation – are slowly rising and that belatedly big business is beginning to move away from an over reliance on cheap foreign labour, undercutting the pay and conditions of indigenous workers and giving rise to higher welfare dependency.It might seem a radical concept, but such employers might just have to pay workers decent wages, train them better, improve their skills and try hard to retain them. That’s why EU workers are still coming to the UK in huge numbers, despite ridiculous Project Fear stories to the contrary.So yes – Brexit will mean higher pay for British workers! Top businessman Stuart Rose, briefly spokesman for the Remain campaign, accurately predicted such a development before the EU Referendum.Regrettably, the multinationals’ trades union, the CBI didn’t get the message: No surprise that they now want no restrictions on foreign workers post Brexit – in other words an endless pool of cheap labour just like now.Likewise, they’re happy to defend the growing gap between average pay and that of FTSE 100 bosses.Ironically, The Prime Minister could still snatch victory from defeat on this issue, notwithstanding her lamentable record as Home Secretary on reducing net immigration to the tens of thousands.The alternative White Paper which David Davis and his Ministers were working on prior to it being dumped at Chequers, was much more evidence-based and looked to many workable international examples of mobility agreements between first world countries like Australia, the United States, Japan and Canada, as a model for future EU-UK immigration arrangements, to our mutual benefit.The policy would have been informed by the Migration Advisory Committee which reports next month, focused on what was the sensible policy for the whole of the UK and all business sectors rather than a noisy minority and their well-paid advocates.It also sought to end the systemic bias towards low paid and low skilled EU citizens over the well qualified from across the globe.It was pro controlled immigration and not about pulling up the drawbridge and that’s where most British voters are now.Will Theresa May use the opportunity to keep faith with the millions of people in the north and the midlands, in south Wales and south west, who look to her to keep her promises and defend their interests and not just those of the well heeled, the multinationals and those comfortable with the Brussels status quo?Will putative leadership contender Sajid Javid have the courage to resist further attempts at craven supplication on continuing free movement in all but name? Will Conservative MPs who benefited from the highest ever blue collar vote for their party in history, ignore their own electors’ concerns and just accept further concessions?The electoral prospects of her party depend on it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
